Summary I have worked for IBM since June 13th, 1966 primarily in a problem solving role and am currently assigned to the High Availability Center of Competency (HACoC) within IBM's Systems and Technology Group. Since 2004, I have lived with my wife, Linda, in Buffalo Valley, Tennessee, about one hour East of Nashville, TN. 
 
During my assignment as a consultant, I have had the pleasure of working with several major companies throughout the world in a variety of industries, including some of the largest banks in the world in China, Brazil, Australia, Germany, the United States and Canada.  
 
In my engagements I see several IT challenges in managing systems and services for High Availability. I believe there is significant opportunity for IT process improvements, especially in establishing appropriate KPIs to drive desired behavior and continuous improvements to enhance process effectiveness and efficiency.  
 
Just some of the common challenges I see are: 
- IT shops are internally focused with little understanding of business requirements and cost of downtime. Service Level Objectives are non-specific and not focused on what is most important to the business. 
- Incomplete Configuration Management database. “ If you don't know what you have, how do you manage it?” 
- Disjointed component monitoring with no correlation to service events. 
Incident Management is really crisis management with little or no focus on preventing incidents and crises.  
- Problem solving stops too soon with defect analysis and does not progress to true Root Cause Analysis. Currently, within the IT industry, Root Cause is largely a 'buzz word', limiting the ability to proactively prevent problems.  
- Change Management is bureaucratic change control and not an enabler of high quality change.
